Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Distributed Algorithms for Near-Planar Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is the development of an algorithmic toolbox to design efficient distributed algorithms for planar and near-planar networks. (Informally, a planar network is one that can be drawn on a two-dimensional surface without any lines crossing.) Many real-world networks and optimization problem instances have a near-planar structure that allows for simpler, more efficient, and often more practical algorithms. The study of such network structures and their algorithmic implications has been a very successful endeavor with a rich theory, many versatile tools, significant algorithmic advances, and drastic performance improvements on problem instances of interest. While modern systems become increasingly larger and more distributed, little is known about how distributed algorithms can be improved on near-planar instances. This project aims to change this and to bring similar improvements to the distributed setting. While its scope is primarily theoretical, the algorithms and general principles to be developed have the potential of laying the groundwork for practical algorithms with real-world impacts. The project will also have a broad educational impact. Much of the research will be done by or in collaboration with graduate students. Furthermore, the proposed research direction features many theoretical questions suitable for undergraduate students without extensive background knowledge and also provides opportunities for experiments and implementation projects. Lastly, the interdisciplinary nature of the problem will likely foster many collaborations between the PI and other researchers in different fields. Any tools and algorithms developed will be shared publicly.

This project will initiate the principled study of distributed algorithms for planar and near-planar networks. In particular, for networks with diameter D and standard bandwidth-limitations (CONGEST model), the project aims at obtaining efficient distributed algorithms running in O(D) synchronous rounds for important standard optimization problems like maximum flow, minimum spanning tree, and various shortest path problems. This approach very timely connects to recent, far-reaching, distributed lower bounds which show that in general (sparse) graphs many optimization problems cannot be computed or even crudely approximated in less than Omega(sqrt(n))-rounds. The PI believes that this proposal provides an exciting new direction for the theory of distributed network optimization algorithms and gives a new perspective on the algorithmic study of planar and near-planar graphs. The expectation is that this broader research direction and the concrete initial results coming out of this project will spark the interest of the community and serve as a basis for a larger and more extensive investigation.

This project aimed at the development of an algorithmic toolbox to design efficient distributed algorithms for planar and near-planar networks. Many real-world networks and optimization problem instances have a near-planar structure that allows for simpler, more efficient, and often more practical algorithms. The study of such network structures and their algorithmic implications has been a very successful endeavor with a rich theory, many versatile tools, significant algorithmic advances, and drastic performance improvements on problem instances of interest. While modern systems become increasingly larger and more distributed, little is known about how distributed algorithms can be improved on near-planar instances. This project changed this and brought significant improvements and new insights about structured (non-worst case) networks to the distributed setting. While its scope was primarily theoretical, the algorithms and general principles developed have the potential to be starting point and part of a larger fundament for practical algorithms with real-world impacts.

The project had a tremendous broader educational impact: This was the first grant for the junior PI which allowed for an immediate and rapid start of a large research group from zero to six PhD students over the three years of this grant. Much of the research was be done by or in collaboration with graduate and undergraduate students in training. Lastly, the interdisciplinary nature of the problems studied fostered many collaborations between the PI and other researchers in different fields. All tools and algorithms developed were published in top venues and as such shared publicly. This project also supported curriculum development activities including the creation of a new graduate level course.

Technical Project Description:
The goal of this project was to initiate the principled study of distributed algorithms for planar and near-planar networks by developing a distributed algorithmic toolbox. In particular, for networks with diameter D and standard bandwidth-limitations (CONGEST model) the project aimed at obtaining efficient distributed algorithms running in O(D) synchronous rounds for important standard optimization problems like maximum flow, minimum spanning tree, and various shortest path problems. This approach very timely connected it to recent, far-reaching, distributed lower bounds which show that in general (sparse) graphs many optimization problems cannot be computed or even crudely approximated in less than Omega(sqrt(n))-rounds.
The project was extremely successful and provided an exciting new direction for the theory of distributed network optimization algorithms. While the grant proposal chiefly aimed at (near)-planar networks the project ended up giving a completely new perspective on the algorithmic study of more structured networks in general and the role topological structure plays with respect to the distributed computational complexity of optimization problems. The development of low-congestion shortcuts cumulated in a complete framework in which many distributed optimization problems such as MST, shortest-path, minimum cuts, etc., and their dependency on the network topology can be jointly and easily be understood. Highlights of this framework include 1) proofs of existence of good shortcuts in many large network classes of interest including bounded genus, small tree- or path-width graphs, expanders, and even any minor closed family of graphs; 2) fast distributed algorithms to find close to optimal shortcuts in any topology; 3) deterministic and message efficient implementations of shortcuts that lead to simultaneously (near) optimal message and time complexities in structured and worst-case topologies for all problems that reduce to shortcuts. Overall this project has developed into a much broader research direction than anticipated, has sparked the interest of the community, and will serve as a basis for larger and more extensive investigations.
